content: It is important to work toward the goal of pulling as a team. Our President needs us as much as we need him. Sometimes people fail, and we have to help them through rough experiences. I only hope that as time passes, President Obama will come to appreciate the crucial role our military and its people play in the very existence and future of our country even more than he does now. To individuals who have never served in uniform, this can be more difficult. I found the choice of words to be poorly chosen as concerns our very dedicated, all-volunteer forces. We all have to start somewhere...many an officer has worked up through the enlisted ranks from 'private' on up into the CWO, line and flag ranks. The whole house depends upon its supporting foundation...so does our team. I'm sure Mr. Obama meant no overt harm, but the arrogant and derisive word 'lowly' is certainly not at all appropriate to describe those lower-ranked individuals who are a major and key part of our whole military team. I was occasionally referred to as a 'lowly' bilge rat, in humor of course, for my then junior-ranking work requirements in the darkest bowels of the ship. My 'rat' work, with my other shipmates, kept the ship (a WW-II destroyer) from flooding the port shaft alley and fire room (boiler/engine room) and possibly capsizing/sinking, after the port shaft stern tube seal failed and ruptured during a fierce hurricane at sea. The 'bilge rats' suddenly became vitally important to ALL ranks aboard the ship! That's teamwork! We are indeed all important and needed, from the newest bootcamp grads to the most seasoned. Stay strong, stay free.

content: Well, as much as people want to rip and roar about a cliche every command officer, including Patton has probably use at one time or another, let's look at one little reality, Infantry folk: If you have to move a platoon across an open area that may be covered with enemy fire, and you don't have the convenience of any covering fire of your own, who does the squad tactics book say you should send across first to find out - Your Platoon Sgt, or the lowest ranking guy? Now, let's say yer in an NBC/CBR situation and all geared/masked up, but you either get the signal that it's all clear, or you think the threat is passed, but either way, you don't have any testing kits to confirm it. What is the procedure in the book to determine the situation?? In both cases, you pick the lowest ranked, least necessary person and send him across, or have him momentarily unmask and observe what happens to him - right? That is reality... If your a bunch of starving sailors in a lost life boat after all the rations have long run out - well, I won't even go there - - But there dang sure is something that is a "lowly" private. It's usually the last guy to come along, that gets all the shyyt details, takes all the bull, and is somewhat expendable, as terrible as that may sound, until the next new guy comes along to fill the bottom rung... But the "lowly private" is absolutely necessary, and by mentioning him, the President acknowledges reality and necessity respectfully at the same time - - Anybody not been there? Wandering and Wondering

content: It is important to work toward the goal of pulling as a team. Our President needs us as much as we need him. Sometimes people fail, and we have to help them through rough experiences. I only hope that as time passes, President Obama will come to appreciate the crucial role our military and its people play in the very existence and future of our country even more than he does now. To individuals who have never served in uniform, this can be more difficult. I found the choice of words to be poorly chosen as concerns our very dedicated, all-volunteer forces. We all have to start somewhere...many an officer has worked up through the enlisted ranks from 'private' on up into the CWO, line and flag ranks. The whole house depends upon its supporting foundation...so does our team. I'm sure Mr. Obama meant no overt harm, but the arrogant and derisive word 'lowly' is certainly not at all appropriate to describe those lower-ranked individuals who are a major and key part of our whole military team. I was occasionally referred to as a 'lowly' bilge rat, in humor of course, for my then junior-ranking work requirements in the darkest bowels of the ship. My 'rat' work, with my other shipmates, kept the ship (a WW-II destroyer) from flooding the port shaft alley and fire room (boiler/engine room) and possibly capsizing/sinking, after the port shaft stern tube seal failed and ruptured during a fierce hurricane at sea. The 'bilge rats' suddenly became vitally important to ALL ranks aboard the ship! That's teamwork! We are indeed all important and needed, from the newest bootcamp grads to the most seasoned. Stay strong, stay free.

content: It is important to work toward the goal of pulling as a team. Our President needs us as much as we need him. Sometimes people fail, and we have to help them through rough experiences. I only hope that as time passes, President Obama will come to appreciate the crucial role our military and its people play in the very existence and future of our country even more than he does now. To individuals who have never served in uniform, this can be more difficult. I found the choice of words to be poorly chosen as concerns our very dedicated, all-volunteer forces. We all have to start somewhere...many an officer has worked up through the enlisted ranks from 'private' on up into the CWO, line and flag ranks. The whole house depends upon its supporting foundation...so does our team. I'm sure Mr. Obama meant no overt harm, but the arrogant and derisive word 'lowly' is certainly not at all appropriate to describe those lower-ranked individuals who are a major and key part of our whole military team. I was occasionally referred to as a 'lowly' bilge rat, in humor of course, for my then junior-ranking work requirements in the darkest bowels of the ship. My 'rat' work, with my other shipmates, kept the ship (a WW-II destroyer) from flooding the port shaft alley and fire room (boiler/engine room) and possibly capsizing/sinking, after the port shaft stern tube seal failed and ruptured during a fierce hurricane at sea. The 'bilge rats' suddenly became vitally important to ALL ranks aboard the ship! That's teamwork! We are indeed all important and needed, from the newest bootcamp grads to the most seasoned. Stay strong, stay free.

content: Well, as much as people want to rip and roar about a cliche every command officer, including Patton has probably use at one time or another, let's look at one little reality, Infantry folk: If you have to move a platoon across an open area that may be covered with enemy fire, and you don't have the convenience of any covering fire of your own, who does the squad tactics book say you should send across first to find out - Your Platoon Sgt, or the lowest ranking guy? Now, let's say yer in an NBC/CBR situation and all geared/masked up, but you either get the signal that it's all clear, or you think the threat is passed, but either way, you don't have any testing kits to confirm it. What is the procedure in the book to determine the situation?? In both cases, you pick the lowest ranked, least necessary person and send him across, or have him momentarily unmask and observe what happens to him - right? That is reality... If your a bunch of starving sailors in a lost life boat after all the rations have long run out - well, I won't even go there - - But there dang sure is something that is a "lowly" private. It's usually the last guy to come along, that gets all the shyyt details, takes all the bull, and is somewhat expendable, as terrible as that may sound, until the next new guy comes along to fill the bottom rung... But the "lowly private" is absolutely necessary, and by mentioning him, the President acknowledges reality and necessity respectfully at the same time - - Anybody not been there? Wandering and Wondering

content: It is important to work toward the goal of pulling as a team. Our President needs us as much as we need him. Sometimes people fail, and we have to help them through rough experiences. I only hope that as time passes, President Obama will come to appreciate the crucial role our military and its people play in the very existence and future of our country even more than he does now. To individuals who have never served in uniform, this can be more difficult. I found the choice of words to be poorly chosen as concerns our very dedicated, all-volunteer forces. We all have to start somewhere...many an officer has worked up through the enlisted ranks from 'private' on up into the CWO, line and flag ranks. The whole house depends upon its supporting foundation...so does our team. I'm sure Mr. Obama meant no overt harm, but the arrogant and derisive word 'lowly' is certainly not at all appropriate to describe those lower-ranked individuals who are a major and key part of our whole military team. I was occasionally referred to as a 'lowly' bilge rat, in humor of course, for my then junior-ranking work requirements in the darkest bowels of the ship. My 'rat' work, with my other shipmates, kept the ship (a WW-II destroyer) from flooding the port shaft alley and fire room (boiler/engine room) and possibly capsizing/sinking, after the port shaft stern tube seal failed and ruptured during a fierce hurricane at sea. The 'bilge rats' suddenly became vitally important to ALL ranks aboard the ship! That's teamwork! We are indeed all important and needed, from the newest bootcamp grads to the most seasoned. Stay strong, stay free.

content: Well, as much as people want to rip and roar about a cliche every command officer, including Patton has probably use at one time or another, let's look at one little reality, Infantry folk: If you have to move a platoon across an open area that may be covered with enemy fire, and you don't have the convenience of any covering fire of your own, who does the squad tactics book say you should send across first to find out - Your Platoon Sgt, or the lowest ranking guy? Now, let's say yer in an NBC/CBR situation and all geared/masked up, but you either get the signal that it's all clear, or you think the threat is passed, but either way, you don't have any testing kits to confirm it. What is the procedure in the book to determine the situation?? In both cases, you pick the lowest ranked, least necessary person and send him across, or have him momentarily unmask and observe what happens to him - right? That is reality... If your a bunch of starving sailors in a lost life boat after all the rations have long run out - well, I won't even go there - - But there dang sure is something that is a "lowly" private. It's usually the last guy to come along, that gets all the shyyt details, takes all the bull, and is somewhat expendable, as terrible as that may sound, until the next new guy comes along to fill the bottom rung... But the "lowly private" is absolutely necessary, and by mentioning him, the President acknowledges reality and necessity respectfully at the same time - - Anybody not been there? Wandering and Wondering
